Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.By Jingo, Keith Abendroth has some brass neck in blaming the catastrophe facing Scottish fishing businesses on the dastardly EU. His solution is even more batty.Driven by resentment and sepia-tinted post-Empire English nationalism, cloaked in talk of Britain and the UK, the Tories have jemmied the UK out of the world’s largest and most successful single market.Having placed the UK as a #third country# outside the EU, alongside Somalia and Kazakhstan, it is not the EU to blame for the barriers to free trade, Mr Abendroth, but the UK government and those who parroted the cruel myths of Brexiteer #sunny uplands#.Mr Abendroth suggests that the fishing industry merely sells into the domestic market as a replacement to EU trade, without thought to the timescales required to repurpose supply lines and create a viable home market # evenit could be done fishing businesses would already be bankrupt.Scotland’s economy and the living standards and opportunities of Scots have been thrown under the wheels of England’s red Brexit bus. Never have the consequences of permitting Westminster to rule our country been more stark.But the time is coming when Scotland will have the historic opportunity to regain the huge benefits of EU membership and become a normal, thriving, independent state at the heart of Europe. There is an empty seat at the top table in Europe # and it won’t be empty for long.Ron Wilson, secretary, Kintyre SNP.Remember the closing stages of the Brexit negotiations  Boris Johnson pretended he was holding out to get the best deal for fishermen. In the end he agreed a deal that the Scottish Fishermen’s Federation described as #desperately poor# and #the worst of both worlds#.Fishermen are restricted to catch fewer fish in most key species. Lorries carrying stocks that have been caught were left to sit at Larkhall – unable to penetrate the new fog of bureaucracy. Scottish fishermen are forced to land the fish they can catch in Denmark – grim news for Scottish fish processors.Instead of trying to fix the problem, Tory Minister Jacob Rees-Mogg says the fish are happier to be British. Of course they are – the fishermen aren’t catching them.The Tories must sort out this mess they have created. Our fishermen and fish processing workers deserve better than silly remarks about happy fish.Councillor Alan Reid, Cowal ward.Keith Abendroth is spot on with his call for the fishing industry in Campbeltown to supply the home market.During my three-and-a-half years in the town it was possible to buy directly from the boat on occasion but it was nigh on impossible to buy fresh live lobster in the town#s fish shop.When I was new to the town , I experienced some shocking service at the some of the small retailers who I always endeavour to support. It is easier to get a full range of seafood and fish in Peebles, about  miles from the sea, which has an excellent fish shop supplied from Eyemouth on the East Coast.Much Welsh shellfish is sent by air to Europe. I often wondered why lorries trundled from Campbeltown across the Rest and Be Thankful and all the way to the English Channel crossings.Much of the st century supply chain is a mystery to me. For instance, much Pacic wild salmon is processed in China before being exported to the UK.  It is an excellent alternative to the farmed version at roughly the same price.Surely a town with an airport could develop a sea product freight service or is it simply down to volume, weight and cost Mark Davey, Peebles.Two weeks ago, at Campbeltown Free Church, we received a letter of thanks from Blythswood Care for filling shoeboxes to support the  Shoe Box Appeal.However, we are aware that many who contributed do not belong to Campbeltown Free Church.So, through the pages of the Courier, can I thank them for their kindness towards people they have never met but whose lives have been enriched by their generosity Dr Rodger M Crooks, Campbeltown Free Church minister.Like many, many other residents in Argyll and Bute I have received through the post a bizarre leaflet from the Liberal Democrats. Bizarre, because it promotes a candidate standing in a completely dferent seat # Caithness, Sutherland and Ross.Meanwhile, the good folk of Caithness, Sutherland and Ross have been equally mystied as to why the hapless Lib Dems have sent them leaflets promoting a candidate in Argyll and Bute!The Lib Dems have certainly lost their way when it comes to their policy on the EU # but it seems that they#ve lost their way in Scotland too.Les Wilson, Islay.Earlier this month the Prime Minister announced a third national lockdown. Although necessary, these measures mean many of our veterans will be facing the next several weeks – or months – completely alone.And while the vaccine rollout out across the country provides some hope, social isolation and loneliness poses a real threat to our elderly this winter, among them many former RAF personnel and their partners supported by the fund.To help combat this, last year the RAF Benevolent Fund introduced a weekly Check and Chat service to support members of the RAF Family experiencing loneliness. I speak to one such gentleman every Tuesday. He lives alone and spent much of  totally isolated and, for him, this service truly is a leline. We chat about what he’s been up to, what he’s cooking for tea, to his time in the RAF and often I’m the only person he will speak to for days.The fund also organises weekly telephone friendship groups, provides access to a listening and counselling service, relationship counselling support, and an online wellbeing portal to help support emotional wellbeing amongst the veteran community.Throughout the pandemic, many of us have learnt more about our neighbours and local community. That’s why we are calling on the people of Scotland to consider whether they know any RAF veterans, or their spouses or widows, who may be experiencing loneliness.To refer someone to the RAF Benevolent Fund, please visit rafbf.org or call   .Air Vice-Marshal Chris Elliot, chief executive, RAF Benevolent Fund.

title: east-lothians-football-clubs-see-remaining-january-matches-postponed
story: Concerns about the ldquoescalating coronavirus situation have seen football from below the Scottish Professional Football LeagueChampionship down, including the East of Scotland Football League , postponed for the rest of January.The Scottish Football Associationboard met on Sunday to discuss the pandemic "and its impact on the national game at all levels".A statement on the governing bodys website said: ldquoFollowing a meeting between the Scottish FA and the Minister for Public Health Sport and Wellbeing, both parties have agreed to impose a temporary suspension of all football beneath the Scottish Professional Football League Championship, encompassing all predominantly part-time tiers of the Scottish professional pyramid, from midnight tonight.ldquoThe impacted leagues are: SPFL League One, SPFL League Two, Scottish Womenrsquos Football Premier Leagues   , Highland League, Lowland League, East, West  South of Scotland Leagues, Scottish Junior FA Leagues and the North Caledonian League.Tranent Juniors were the only East Lothian team in action over the weekend as their Scottish Cup adventure came to an end at East Fe.The Belters, who sit top of the EOSFL Premier Division, were due to face Dundonald Bluebell this weekend but no games will now take place until February  at the earliest.Fellow Premier Division sides Musselburgh Athletic and Dunbar United were due to face Sauchie and Crossgates respectively this weekend, while Ormiston were due to welcome Kirkcaldy and Dysart, and Haddington Athletic were facing St Andrews in the First Division Conference A.Preston Athletic were not scheduled to have a game this weekend.However, those games will all now need to be rescheduled.Rod Petrie, Scottish FA president, said: ldquoThe Scottish FA is well aware of the efforts all clubs take to comply with the exacting protocols that were conditional on elite football being given an exemption to continue amid the pandemic.ldquoNonetheless, the continuation of football at all levels has weighed increasingly heavy on me as president, my colleagues on the board and the joint response group as we have watched the new strain of the virus spread rapidly.ldquoWhile national sport has been afforded the privilege of elite sporting exemption, the risk of mass transportation of untested, largely part-time players is something that cannot be sustained as the cases continue to rise and available hospital beds become increasingly scarce.ldquoAfter discussions with the SPFL, the Premiership and Championship will continue on the proviso that both adhere to the existing testing regime.ldquoThe vast majority of teams in those isions are full-time professional clubs and so the risk of transmission remains manageably low.ldquoThe cost implications to lower-ision clubs was one factor but so too the realisation that many ndash with some notable exceptions ndash consist of part-time players who are either prevented from working due to the virus or have to work.ldquoIn either case, the risk is currently too great amid the developing nationwide spread of the virus.

title: letter-week-new-super-school-prestonpans-blindwells
story: Under the local plan, construction of a new secondary school is already scheduled to cope with the later stages of the Blindwells development.Pending this new school being built, I imagine unsightly and unsatisfactory Portakabins will be added onto the already dilapidated Preston Lodge building, overcrowding its school hall and other facilities.Would it not be far better to establish a new purpose-built super school, which would be able to cope with the combined school populations of both the Blindwells and Prestonpans areas, and also to start building this much earlier than currently envisaged I recently suggested this idea with a local councillor. While he liked the concept in principle, he indicated that the current agreement with the Blindwells developer meant that the council would not be able to afford going ahead with such a project.This is because the developer is not obliged to produce any funds for a secondary school at Blindwells until a much later stage in the projectrsquos development.However, I have read recently in the Courier of least one instance ndash the postponing of improved access roads ndash where the council appears prepared to be bending over backwards to accommodate changes in the Blindwells development plan to suit the developer. Would it not be reasonable for the council to ask the developerthey might now reciprocate, by acceleratingtheir contribution to the arearsquos school estate Building a new secondary lsquosuper schoolrsquo earlier than now planned would substantially enhance the sales value of the new houses in the first stages of the Blindwells development, as well as provide a better pupil experience for everyone in the Prestonpans cluster.Angus TullochLongniddry

title: bbc-golf-documentary-iron-women-features-east-lothian-pioneers
story: And the BBC Alba documentary teed off in Musselburgh ndash home to Musselburgh Links, one of the oldest golf courses in the world.Screened on January , the story of Iron Women began in the th century in the Honest Toun, with recorded evidence of fishwives playing golf and competing for the prize of a creel and silk handkerchiefs.It is the latest documentary created by filmmaker Margot McCuaig, who said: ldquoWomenrsquos golf in Scotland has a long and prestigious history.ldquoDespite barriers, both in terms of attitude and physical structures, pioneers have continued to lead the way.ldquoConsequently, sporting celebrities have emerged as role models, on and off the green, ensuring that there has been a fairer way for women.ldquoWhether playing professionally or competitively at amateur level, golf has a common theme. Friendships are created and cherished, time on the course is relished and iron women have continued to make their mark, and their own home, in Scottish golf.Produced by Glasgow-based independent production company purpleTV, the documentary explores the history of womenrsquos golf in Scotland and celebrates some of the little-known female pioneers.Golf was traditionally regarded as a manrsquos sport ndash a protected male environment that was out of bounds to the so-called weaker sex.From the early pioneers of the th century to role models who challenged the patriarchal constraints of male-dominated golfing arenas, the story celebrates the trailblazers who put Scottish womenrsquos golf firmly on the world map.The game gathered momentum among the Victorian ladies of St Andrews from , albeit under the watchful gaze of husbands and fathers who controlled the spaces women frequented, and how they used them.Over the centuries, while some women were open about their love for golf, their space was often severely curtailed and distinctive male and female spheres came into play.Transgressors such as Issette Pearson and Agnes Grainger developed strategies to create opportunities for women and, thanks to their determination, the Ladies Golf Union and the Scottish Ladies Golf Association were formed in  and  respectively, formalising the sport, creating competition and, fundamentally, a handicap system before men.Formidable golfers emerged, with several Scots leading the way at home and abroad.Professional golfer Karyn Dallas gives a shocking account of arriving at a club to play a tournament and finding a sign that said: ldquoNo dogs or women allowed.While Dr Fiona Skillen, womenrsquos golf historian and lecturer in history at Glasgow Caledonian University, said men ldquosupervised women to make sure they behaved appropriately when they played golf in the th century and land was gted to the St Andrews Ladies Putting Club.Dr Skillen said: ldquoItrsquos interesting that the land the women are gted to play on is straight beside the Royal and Ancient Clubhouse, so therersquos an argument there that this is in order for the men to be able to keep a watchful eye on what the women are getting up to.ldquoThe men check to seethe women are behaving themselves in a circumspect manner.ldquoThey are being encouraged to play but a very specic kind of golf itrsquos putting, itrsquos not challenging.She also shares memories of being in a golf club as a child, adding: ldquoI remember my dad getting very antsyI ever went near the painted line orI tried to step over the painted line. It was hugely controversial and I was very aware of the gendered behaviour and the dference.Dr Fiona Reid, who joined North Berwick Golf Club  years ago and is a member of Murrayfield Golf Club in Edinburgh, had a similar experience and recalls a white line in the golf club where her mum played.She said: ldquoOnly the men could go over that line.ldquoTherersquos a place that the men can go and a place that the women can go.Gillian Kirkwood also remembers being prohibited from walking past the window of the menrsquos lounge at a golf club.She said: ldquoYou werenrsquot allowed to walk past the golf club window ndash you had to walk on a path that was quite far away from the window so that the men didnrsquot see you and you canrsquot look in at the window to see the men having their drinks and cigars.ldquoSome golf clubs really had to be dragged into the st century.Now based in Gullane, she played county golf during the s and s.She played for Broomieknowe Golf Club in Edinburgh, where she won the club championship four times.She was also captain of Broomieknowe Golf Club when she was in her s.Brogan Clark, from Lochgelly in Fe, who was  when she got into the Scottish Golf Academy, said: ldquoIf you were in front of a group of guys at tee time, yoursquod hear them huffing and saying: lsquoWersquore at the back of these ladies and itrsquos going to be a five or six-hour round.rsquoldquoThat kind of gave you the satisfaction to go up to the first tee and hit the ball and see their jaw drop!Iron Women is available to watch on BBC iPlayer until the end of this month.

title: ice-cream-servery-created-newhailes-musselburgh
story: Drainage pipes will also be installed as part of the project at the visitor attraction, with its Palladian-style country house, which is run by the National Trust for Scotland .An NTS spokesperson said: ldquoWersquore pleased that this development can go ahead. It continues our work to revitalise visitor facilities at Newhailes House and Garden, one of Scotlandrsquos national treasures.It is hoped that work will start in the next few weeks, Covid- restrictions permitting. The plan is to open the ice cream servery for the summer season.The facility is part of the charityrsquos pound. million Newhailes revival project, which was launched in   to breathe new le into the house and its general landscape.This involved restoration of parts of the estate, including developing the walled garden into a community garden, and the creation of Weehailes playpark.In October , planning permission was granted for the conversion and alteration of the building to provide a visitor centre, cafe, offices, five houses and one flat, including the formation of a car park and associated landscaping works, accessed off Newhailes Road. This work has partly been carried out as the five houses have not been created.In August , the go-ahead was given for alterations and change of use of storage areas and flat to extend the visitor centre, including the provision of an extended cafe with outdoor seating area, shop, offices and public toilet facilities.The nationally important stables are listed Category A as being of special architectural or historic interest.A planning report for the new ice cream servery stated: ldquoThe intention is to serve customers a takeaway ice cream service to expand and enhance the existing visitor, cafe and retail facilities at Newhailes.ldquoThis in turn would ensure that the Newhailes Estate would remain an attractive and viable tourist attraction within the Edinburgh Green Belt.ldquoThe proposed change of use of this part of the building would conserve the form and character of this part of the Newhailes Stables complex. The proposals do not include the erection of any new buildings or alterations to the external appearance of the buildings. There will be no change to the built form of the Newhailes Stable complex and therefore the proposals would not harm green belt objectives or the character or appearance of the local area, including this part of the Edinburgh Green Belt.Historic Environment Scotland raised no objection to the proposals and was satisfied that they did not raise issues of national signicance with regard to the effect of the development on Newhailes Garden and Designed Landscape.In , the estate was purchased by the powerful and influential Dalrymple dynasty in the form of Sir David, st Baronet of Hailes, who served as Scotlandrsquos Solicitor General and Lord Advocate.In the decades that followed, Newhailes came to be seen as one of Scotlandrsquos most beautul Palladian-style country houses, set among extensive, landscaped grounds.

title: ceremony-held-memory-musselburghs-david-macbeth-moir
story: Although the tribute to David Macbeth Moir, who was the townrsquos medical officer, takes place annually, it was particularly poignant this year amidst the coronavirus pandemic.In a low-key event, David Stillie, Old Musselburgh Club president, was accompanied by club treasurer Ian Wood, who took a photograph of the wreath-laying commemoration at the statue of the physician, on Mall Avenue, to mark the rd anniversary of his birth.Usually in attendance are Iain and Marion Moir ndash descendants of Dr Moir ndash from Edinburgh and a larger number of club members, who were unable to pay their respects this year due to the social distancing regulations.Mr Stillie said: ldquoIt is interesting that in the midst of this pandemic, we should be commemorating the le of a dedicated physician who worked so hard during the cholera epidemic in .A service that traditionally takes place at a local church was also cancelled due to restrictions.Born in Musselburgh on January , , Dr Macbeth Moir worked as a doctor throughout his le and was the townrsquos medical officer in , during the cholera epidemics which badly affected the local community.Also a writer, he adopted the Greek letter Delta as his pen name.Mr Stillie outlined Dr Moirrsquos le, saying he was the second of four children and attended Musselburgh Grammar School for six years, learning Greek, Latin, French, geography and algebra.At the age of , he was apprenticed to Dr Stewart in Musselburgh and showed an aptitude for the medical profession.He studied medicine at Edinburgh University and gained a diploma in surgery in . A year later, he became a partner in Dr Brownrsquos practice in Musselburgh.Mr Stillie described him as ldquoa man of energy and compassion, as can be seen from his unstinting work attending to patients, preparing reports and writing of his observations on the progress of the  cholera epidemic that ravaged the country.His pamphlet, entitled lsquoPractical Observations on Malignant Cholerarsquo, sold out within two days.Dr Moirrsquos writing career started in , with two essays published locally, and from  onwards he was a regular contributor to the Scots Magazine, the Edinburgh Magazine, Fraserrsquos Magazine and the Edinburgh Literary Gazette.He also contributed some  works to Blackwoodrsquos Magazine.Mr Stillie highlighted Dr Moirrsquos poem written for the Burns Festival in  and later published in Blackwoodrsquos Magazine, and his poem lsquoScenery of the River Eskrsquo.Dr Moir married in  and had  children, three of whom died in childhood. He was encouraged by his peers, including Wordsworth, Tennyson and Dickens, to publish his Domestic Verses , which are considered to be some of his best work.A member of the Kirk Session at St Michaelrsquos Church, he was also a councillor.Dr Moir was injured as a result of a carriage accident, which left him lame, and a further injury in  affected his general health, leading to his death in Dumfries later that year.Mr Stillie said: ldquoHe was held in such high regard by the townspeople of Musselburgh, particularly for his work during the cholera epidemic, that his body was ed to the town and he was given a civic funeral attended by the town council, local dignitaries and many of his literary contemporaries.ldquoA public subscription funded the statue at the end of the Rennie Bridge, which was sculpted by the famous local sculptor Alexander Handyside Ritchie.He added: ldquoDavid Macbeth Moir was a man orsquo pairts, educated, cultured, compassionate and it is regrettable that so little is remembered of his literary work and his unremitting commitment to the people of this town at a time of great tragedy.

title: former-north-berwick-man-tali-campbell-finding-ice-hockey-success-canada
story: Tali Campbell, , who lives in Nanaimo, Vancouver Island, was born in Edinburgh and lived on North Berwickrsquos Lochbridge Road until the age of three, when his parents split and he moved with mum Sam and sisters Tina and Danielle to Canada.His brother Angus stayed behind to finish high school in North Berwick before also moving to Canada.While Angus played football in Scotland, Tali showed more of an interest in the Canadian national sport and decided to get into management ndash an ambition he has realised, becoming the youngest general manager of a British Columbia Hockey Leagueteam.Tali, now vice-president and GM of the Coquitlam Express Junior A Hockey Club, said: ldquoIrsquove never played ice hockey at all.ldquoI grew up watching a lot of soccer, then I started watching the local hockey team and started volunteering.ldquoI started six years ago as game day co-ordinator [for Alberni Valley Bulldogs], then moved into more of a sales and marketing role, then eventually became director of business operations [at Nanaimo Clippers], then general manager and I am now GM of the Express.But Tali is not fazed by his meteoric rise.He said: ldquoBCHL is touted as the best junior hockey league in North America ndash our goal is to help these --year-old kids get National Collegiate Athletic Associationscholarships, to go and play hockey for schools, and of course to get into the National Hockey League .ldquoBeing GM, I would say, is the highest position in junior hockey for a club your job is to manage the  players, the budgets off the ice, all the programmes.ldquoWe operate about a Can.million budget, so I sit at the governorsrsquo table. Itrsquos pretty cool.Tali manages to get to North Berwick to visit his Scottish family at least once a year ndash but was unable to last year due to lockdown.He said: ldquoI try and get there in the summer when itrsquos a bit quieter for hockey.ldquoItrsquos tough [not being able to travel]. My grandparents are getting a bit older now so we try to get over every year.ldquoBut with technology, you do stuff like FaceTime.Talirsquos dad Gus still lives on Lochbridge Road with his we Kirsty and son Ryan, , while Talirsquos granddad, also called Angus, lives with we Margaret at Cemetery Lodge at North Berwick Cemetery.Gus couldnrsquot be prouder of his ambitious son.He said: ldquoIrsquom very proud of him, hersquos done very well.ldquoIrsquove never been interested in ice hockey but hersquos been into it most of his le.ldquoBeing in Canada, he went to see his local team and he had a dream one day to manage them, so it happened!Gus, who is plant nursery manager for East Lothian Council, added: ldquoWhen he was over here he took me to see the Edinburgh Capitals, to see my first game and Irsquove always wanted to go over to Canada to see hockey there.ldquoTalirsquos some man hersquos self-motivated and driven.Tali said: ldquoI love this job, I love working with these younger guys and helping them achieve their goal.ldquoGrowing up, I was very interested in sports but was never a good athlete, so I took the business route.ldquoThe next level up would be the American Hockey League or the NHL but in the back of my mind I always think of the Olympics. Great Britain doesnrsquot have the best hockey team and I would love to do that one day ndash manage Team Great Britain.Tali, who has dual citizenship, added: ldquoIrsquom Canadian but I was born Scottish ndash Irsquove got a tattoo on my leg of a Canadian and Scottish flag ndash and I think the ultimate goal would be to be GM of Team Great Britain one day.

title: apartments-planned-former-manse-dunbar
story: The building on Dunbarrsquos Bayswell Road is currently empty, with development going on around it.Development of the site has been split into three phases, with  apartments already created to the east of the manse.Another planning application, which aims to ldquorespond to the shortage of affordable housing and provides  new apartments which are conveniently located in close proximity to Dunbar town centre, has been lodged with East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department, with a decision yet to be made.Now, the latest proposals look at the manse, which faces out towards the North Sea.On the ground floor, a one-bedroom and a three-bedroom flat would be created, with six parking spaces outside.Upstairs, a two-bedroom flat would be created on both the first and second floors.Consideration was previously given to transforming the building back into a single house. However, a design and access statement included with the latest planning application ruled that out.The document reads: ldquoThe old manse is currently empty following the decision by the former tenant, Church of Scotland, to relocate their social work services to an alternative location.ldquoGiven the previous and historic residential use of the building, it is now considered timely and appropriate to revert this vacant building back to a residential use.ldquoThe building has had several internal alterations over the years and as such will benefit from a comprehensive internal remodelling to bring the building up to st-century standards.ldquoRather than try to provide a single residential unit, we consider that a more appropriate use will be to split the building into four units, thereby complying with good practice on appropriate re-use of buildings and making efficient use of land for housing.Externally, little change is proposed to the look of the building, with repainting and repairs to be carried out.The developer described the proposals as ldquopositive and noted it formed part of the overall redevelopment of the site.A decision is expected towards the end of next month.

title: walk-scott-foundation-hopes-hold-walk-september
story: The Walk With Scott Foundationhad wanted to host an Infinity Walk spanning two days over the first weekend in May.However, that has been temporarily postponed, with plans for the walk to take place in May next year instead.A spokeswoman for the Tranent-based charity said: ldquoGiven the ongoing Covid- challenges, the WWSF board has regrettably concluded that these dates [May ] are now unrealistic.ldquoHowever, instead of the May dates, we have decided to delay the walk to Saturday, September ,  , where we plan to arrange a one-day marathon- walk across East Lothian.ldquoThe details are still being worked through and will be released in due course.Walk With Scott was started by Tranent fundraiser Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday in May .Scott passed away on New Yearrsquos Day last year.Since its inception in , the event has raised more than pound, for local charities and good causes.

title: medical-grade-face-mask-can-buy-one
story: While the wearing of cloth masks has become routine, the idea of upgrading to a specialised version has caught many people by surprise.Last week, Germany became the first major European country to require the medical grade protection for people in shops and on publictransport - but there is no such requirement in the UK.Mr Swinney said officials inScotlandwere mulling over introducing the tougher action as mutated strains of Covid- piles pressure on hospitals and NHS services.Deputy First Minister John SwinneyWhat is a medical face mask The World Health Organisationdefines medical masks as: lsquosurgical or procedure masks that are flat or pleated they are affixed to the head with straps that go around the ears or head or both.rsquoCrucially, a medical-grade mask must have at least a % droplet filtration system, breathability and consist of multiple layers of manufactured, non-woven materials such as polypropylene, polyethylene or cellulose. This level of protection ensures that all but % of droplets from the mouth are caught by the mask - cutting of one of the major sources of trabnsmission of Covid .Cloth masks, while effective, are thought to catch between around -% of droplets, although this ies depending on the make.The WHO advice continues: "Medical masks are rectangular in shape and comprise three or four layers. Each layer consists of fine to very fine fibres. These masks are tested for their ability to block droplets and particles."The masks must block droplets and particles while at the same time they must also be breathable by allowing air to pass."A medical-grade maskWhere can I buy a medical face mask While stocks of masks - along with all other types of medical protective equipment - became scarce almost overnight at the beginning of the pandemic, supplies have now rebounded and boxes of masks are available online at Amazon, online chemists and other retailers.However, a sudden surge in buyers could result in stocks dwindling again so people are being asked to wait until official advice changes.Should I stop wearing my cloth mask In no circumstances should people stop wearing cloth masks. While not as good as a medical grade mask, they are still an important tool in the fight against the spread of the disease.        name : ballot,target: ballot_,params:.push

title: bomb-squad-called-factory-producing-uk-covid-vaccine
story: Police have put a cordon in place near the Wockhardt plant at Wrexham industrial estate and the public have been asked to stay away.A spokesperson for North Wales Police said: "We are currently dealing with an ongoing incident on the Wrexham Industrial Estate."The roads are currently closed and we would ask the public to avoid the area until further notice."The factory which has the capacity to produce  million doses of the vaccine a year for distribution around the UK is currently closed off.In a statement, the company which operates the site and is a supply partner for AstraZeneca, Wockhardt UK, said the estate has been partially evacuated while experts investigate the package.It said: "Wockhardt UK in Wrexham this morning received a suspicious package.ldquoRelevant authorities have responded and upon expert advice we have partially evacuated the site pending a full investigation.ldquoThe safety of our employees and business continuity remain of paramount importance."The industrial estate is considered a sensitive site given its role in the UKrsquos Covid vaccination rollout.Prime Minister Boris Johnson visited the site in November last year describing the lab as a ldquosalvation for humainity.Mr Johnson said: "This could,were lucky,everything goes right - be available just in a few weeks."This could - and I stress could - really be the salvation for humanity, these vaccines, not just this one but obviously all the vaccines that are currently being developed."

title: high-school-musical-star-vanessa-hudgens-filming-east-lothian
story: Filming for the movie The Princess Switch  is now underway, with some scenes shot on the Gosford Estate, by Longniddry, before Christmas.The cast and crew have also been spotted recently in Midlothian, at Newbattle Abbey College in Dalkeith the former monastery was transformed into a winter wonderland, with fake snow, a nativity scene and fir trees.Scotland is a popular location for the film franchise, with several parts of Edinburgh and local dancers and schoolchildren also all featuring in the previous movies.The film stars Vanessa Hudgens, who played Gabriella Montez in Disneyrsquos worldwide smash High School Musical she plays both a talented baker and a duchess who look exactly the same and who swap lives.Filming is taking place on private estates to keep cast and crew away from congested areas, due to the coronavirus pandemic.: Rockstar Phoebe Bridgers films music video at YellowcraigThe filming of movies and television shows has been given the green light by the Scottish Government to continue through lockdown, but all cast and crew must follow sector guidelines, which include keeping away from members of the public.Current coronavirus guidelines also include enhanced mask wearing.Vanessa is not residing in East Lothian during her time in Scotland, though. . . she has been staying in a luxury suite at The Balmoral hotel in Edinburgh.The first Princess Switch film was released in  the second in November last year.It is thought this new addition to the franchise will be released on Netflix this Christmas.

title: speed-covid-vaccine-rollout-labelled-unacceptable-iain-gray-msp
story: Speed of Covid vaccine rollout labelled ‘unacceptable’Mr Henry Abbieis given GullaneMedical Practice’s first Covltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtid- vaccination, oltspan classtruncate-full-screengtn January. Dr Andrew Smith, GP partner, ‘did the honours’. Inset:East Lothian MSP Iain Graydescribed the slow rollout across the county as ldquoworrying and called on Scottish Government ministers to ldquoup their game as the race to protect vulnerable groups continues.The latest figures show that , people had been vaccinated across the county up to Sunday, January  ndash . per cent of the countyrsquos population.This placed East Lothian as the third slowest council area in Scotland for vaccines being administered.NHS Lothian confirmed that  of East Lothianrsquos  care homes had completed their rollout by January , despite all of Midlothianrsquos care homes being fully vaccinated by that time. All care homes in East Lothian will be vaccinated by tomorrow , it has been pledged.East Lothian has one of the highest percentages of older residents in Scotland and is one of the fastest growing council areas. Just under nine per cent of the population is over the age of , higher than the Scottish national average.Mr Gray said: ldquoIt is unacceptable that the percentage of older people in East Lothian who have received their first dose of the vaccine is less than that of the majority of other areas and that vaccinations in our care homes are also lagging behind.ldquoWhatever the reasons for this, the NHS and GPs must be supported to recty the situation to ensure that people here receive the vaccine as quickly as possible.ldquoThese worrying figures have emerged at the same time as Scotland-wide concerns about the speed of the rollout of the vaccine programme here, compared with the rest of the UK. As has been said so often in recent weeks, we are in a race against the virus and Ministers must up their game to ensure that we do not fall behind on targets for vaccinating priority groups.A spokesperson for East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnership said all care homes in East Lothian would be fully vaccinated with their first doses by tomorrow .And East Lothian MP Kenny MacAskill called for people to cut those delivering the vaccines lsquosome slackrsquo.He said: ldquoItrsquos an unprecedented situation and challenging for all. Prioritising care homes was sensible evenit has resulted in a slower roll out. It was after all also following scientic advice. Wersquod all like it to be faster and easier. But all involved are trying and cutting them some slack and thanking them for their efforts will work better than carping.Concern over the slow delivery of the vaccines to people in the community were also raised with Prestonpans community councillor Calum Miller criticising NHS Lothian for the slow roll-out, amid claims that local doctors had been left unable to deliver the jabs because of a lack of supplies.He said: ldquoNHS Lothian have had months to prepare for this crucial vaccine roll-out and once again they have dropped the ball.lsquoConcentrating on care homesrsquo is just an excuse, they could and should be vaccinating dferent categories of over-s at the same time.ldquoMany could easily make their way to Roodlands [the East Lothian Community Hospital in Haddington]we had a local vaccination facility.ldquoScotland has hit the ground snoring with this roll-out and we need to wake up fast.Queen Margarety University has been named as one of four mass vaccination centres in Lothian which will oversee the distribution of the first vaccine doses as it moves into the wider priority groups.It is expected to open its centre on February  NHS Lothian confirmed yesterday evening .It will have  stations and be capable of vaccinating , people a week.SEE MORE:Date announced for opening of drive-through Covid vaccination centre in East LothianJohn Swinney, deputy First Minister, insisted this week that the vaccination programme was on track despite concerns raised about the speed of the roll-out.Opposition parties said the rollout is ldquoslow and sluggish and that there was a ldquopostcode lottery of availability.Mr Swinney, however, said: ldquoGood progress has been made on the delivery of the vaccine for over-s. We have got to % on care home residents, who are most at risk of morbidity from Covid.ldquoWe are in a majority now in over-s and that task will be completed by the end of the first week in February, and we will move onto the next priority group and complete that by the middle of February as announced.David Small, director of primary care transformation and Covid vaccination project lead, NHS Lothian, insisted all over s would be offered the opportunity to receive the jab at their GP practices by next Friday, February .He said: ldquoWe understand that there is concern that some over-s have not yet been invited for vaccination at GP clinics.ldquoGP practices are vaccinating their patients as fast as their vaccine supplies allow.ldquoVaccines are being sent directly to GPs from the UK national distributor and neither GP practices nor NHS Lothian can influence the timings or quantities of the deliveries received.ldquoThe supply chain for the vaccine is at times uneven and can be subject to delays however,  per cent of GP practices have received a delivery of the vaccine and are currently in the process of getting more supplies.The latest vaccine stats from the Scottish Government up to Sunday, January , showed , people in East Lothian had received their first dose .In Midlothian, the figure rose to , or . per cent of the population.Edinburgh saw , vaccines issued but that equalled . per cent of its population, giving it the lowest rate of delivery in Scotland.

title: date-announced-opening-drive-through-covid-vaccination-centre-queen-margaret-university
story: It will have  stations and be capable of vaccinating , people a week.Other large centres in Edinburgh and West Lothian will begin vaccinating patients on Monday as part of wave two of the national vaccination programme.These include the Edinburgh International Conference Centre , which will be capable of vaccinating more than , people a week.East Lothian Community Hospital, in Haddington, has also been named as a smaller, more localised vaccination centre, along with many other community hubs in Edinburgh, Midlothian and West Lothian.David Small, of NHS Lothian, said they had already vaccinated "the vast majority of the first cohort to be prioritised" in the Lothians."GP practices continue to deliver the injections as fast as their vaccine supplies allow," he said.ldquoThis is a signicant moment as we embark on wave two of the largest vaccination programme that has ever been undertaken.ldquoWe need to vaccinate as many people as we possibly can to help save lives and provide protection to help communities get back to normal."We therefore urge people to attend their appointment once they are notied of the details."NHS Lothian has been working with councils, health and social care partnerships and other partners in recent weeks to ensure the sites are ready.The centres are the first of a total of  to be rolled out across Lothian, including the community hospital in Haddington.People aged between - and those most clinically vulnerable will be given appointments to be vaccinated by their GP, while those aged between - and  to  will be invited into mass vaccination sites and smaller community venues for their injections.Patients are being urged to keep their first appointment in order to provide protection to as many people, as quickly as possible eventheir appointment venue may not be the one that is closest to where they live.Smaller community clinics will deliver vaccinations in the local area for people with complex needs or who, for other reasons, absolutely cannot and would not be expected to travel to a mass centre.If patients absolutely cannot keep the appointment they have been given, they are being asked to call the Covid- Vaccination Helpline on    to rearrange their appointment. If they are aged  and over, they should phone their GP practice to rearrange your appointment.

title: east-lothian-council-advertises-94-000-vacancies
story: The heads of service roles are part of a restructuring of the councilrsquos Central Management Team , which the local authority says will save pound, annually.Chief executive Monica Patterson had two depute chief executives, while a director of health and social care partnership oversaw six heads of service and four chief operating officers.However, the chief operating officersrsquo roles have been removed and a new executive director post created.The new CMT line-up comprises the chief executive, four executive directors ndash including the director of the health and social care partnership ndash and nine heads of service.Heads of service posts for education, corporate support, housing, and development are being advertised via recruitment specialist Solace, with a salary of pound, for a -hour week.The restructure was criticised by SNP councillors, who refused to support it when it was put before council for approval behind closed doors in November.Councillor Stuart CurrieCouncillor Stuart Currie, SNP group leader, questioned the decision to create an additional executive ldquopound,-plus post, saying: ldquoWe donrsquot need any more chiefs right now, what is needed is support for workers at the coal face.Ms Patterson, chief executive, said at the time: ldquoOur priority is to ensure that East Lothian Council continues to have a senior leadership team with the talent, vision and capacity to think and act strategically, and engage with our communities and partners, to deliver the very best for East Lothian in dynamic and challenging circumstances."It remains a very dficult financial environment, compounded by the Covid- pandemic, which means we must maintain the pace of transformation in continuing to deliver high-quality and efficient services.A council spokesperson added: ldquoChief officer salaries are published publicly every year in the councilrsquos annual accounts."The salary for the executive director posts this year is the same as the depute chief executive posts being replaced ndash pound,. Agreement on annual pay awards is made at a national level.

title: brunton-theatre-groups-heading-online
story: In March, , all youth and adult theatre groups were postponed due to the Covid- pandemic, and they went online.A spokesperson for the Musselburgh-based Brunton Theatre said: ldquoLike many other art forms, the classes went online, providing an opportunity for fun, interaction and creativity ndash a fantastic tonic to trying times.Thanks to funding The Brunton Theatre Trust secured through Creative Scotland, the youth theatre network and Brunton Players are able to continue online programmes this year, with classes being offered for a low fee.The sessions will recommence online from Monday, February  and run for eight weeks, continuing through the February school break.All classes are led by experienced and qualied drama professionals.This term, some of the ELYT groups will be working with Wonder Fools, a charity and theatre company, on its lsquoPositive Stories For Negative Timesrsquo project.Wonder Fools has commissioned five plays by UK writers, which have been made available online for community theatre, charity and youth groups to perform.The company also provides a framework about how to rehearse, direct and record the works. The final performances will be filmed and uploaded to the internet, alongside all other performances made as part of this project, where they will be free to view.The Brunton spokesperson said feedback for the online youth theatre classes has been very positive.Brunton Players is a community theatre group for adults and usually meets weekly at The Brunton, with performances on stage at the Musselburgh venue.Now, participants are enjoying being creative together and practising performance skills online, with weekly workshops.The spokesperson added: ldquoThis is a great way to combat isolation and use creativity to have fun. New members are very welcome no previous experience is required.More information is available at www.thebrunton or contact youththeatre@eastlothian.gov.uk

title: driver-slammed-touring-north-coast-500-lockdown
story: Adam Jarguz posted on a social media site for owners of the Seat Leon MK car that he had made the three-day road trip last week.Alongside pictures he had taken on his journey was a caption that read ldquoNC complete.He added that he camped on the route, as hotels and BBs were closed, and did not encounter anyone during the trip, using pay-at-pump services for fuel.Under current Scottish Government lockdown restrictions, it is against the law to leave your home for anything other than an essential reason, with people urged to avoid unnecessary travel.Mr Jarguz has been criticised by members of the public who live along the route and by the North Coast  Ltd company.Tom Campbell, executive chairman of North Coast  Ltd, said: ldquoWe strongly condemn any irresponsible or anti-social behaviour conducted by a minority of visitors on the NC and would urge people always to report such behaviour to Police Scotland and other relevant authorities in the first instance.Margaret Meek, co-founder of NC The Land Weeps social media page, said: ldquoItrsquos not a grey area:itrsquos illegal to go from East Lothianto the Highlands for a jaunt for non-essential travel.ldquoObviously he did not drive  miles on a round trip and not get out of his car. Itrsquos not rocket science.Ali Gillespie, from Inverness, who spotted the social media post, said: ldquoYou only need to look at whatrsquos happening in Barra to see what happens when Covid arrives in wee places where locals arenrsquot expecting it.ldquoSelfish in the extreme.Mr Jarguz could not be reached for comment.

title: cameron-susan-law-say-goodbye-gullanes-mallard-hotel
story: The Mallard, on the villagersquos East Links Road, has been owned and managed by husband-and-we Susan and Cameron Law since .It was previously owned by Susanrsquos parents, Iain and Flora Clark, who took the business over in , after running a restaurant in Pitlochry.Iain chose the hotelrsquos name after being inspired by the wildle in Aberlady Bay.Sadly, he died four years later but Flora, Susan and the rest of the family worked together to keep the business going.When Flora died in , Susan and Cameron took over The Mallard.Susan said: ldquoHotel le is quite challenging sometimes, but wersquove met lots and lots of great people over the years.ldquoIt is quite sad in these Covid times people have had to give up businesses for financial reasons but we are really lucky that that was not the case for us.ldquoMy dad always used to say lsquohospitality with informalityrsquo, which is what we strove to achieve. We will miss hotel le.The pair had always planned to retire at this time but hopes for a large party have been scuppered due to the pandemic.As well as enjoying time with family, friends, and a new grandchild who was born in December, Susan and Cameron will be kept busy by their many hobbies and interests.Susan is former chairman and current service co-ordinator at Muirfield Riding Therapy, receiving an MBE for her work there and Cameron is a member at North Berwick Golf Club. They also plan to travel, when lockdown restrictions allow.But first on the to-do list is househunting. Susan has lived on the hotelrsquos premises since her parents owned it, with Cameron moving in after their marriage in .The pair, who previously ran The Ugly Duckling cafe in the village, will not be moving far and plan to stay in East Lothian, a community they have grown to love.Susan called the ending ldquobittersweet, adding that ldquoit is really hard to pick out just one memory from the past -and-a-half years of her family running The Mallard.She said she would rather pay tribute to and thank all the customers, guests and staff who had been a huge part of their lives. She added: ldquoWe have not been able to say proper goodbyes to people, which is quite sad.ldquoSome of them have been coming to the hotel for over  years.ldquoIrsquove said to the new owners that I want to meet up with some of the guests and say goodbye properly.ldquoAmong the plans was a two-day open-door party to allow people to drop in and say farewell.ldquoWorking in a hotel is an all-consuming business so retirement will take some getting used to. I donrsquot want to become a couch potato though! I donrsquot feel old enough to retire at all.: Ambitious plans for village hotelPlans last year by Structured House Group to demolish and replace the hotel with a new -bedroomed version will not go ahead.The Mallard has now been sold to East Lothian-based company Watchman Inns the hotelrsquos name is being changed to The Watchman and it is currently undergoing a refurbishment, with hopes it will reopen in July.Susan said that, with the name change, it was like she was ldquotaking [The Mallard name] with them, adding that it would be ldquoin our hearts and memories.The lettering that spells out the hotelrsquos name on the front of the building have also been gted to Susan and Cameron.

title: east-lothian-councils-carbon-footprint-reduction-continues
story: The figures, released in a report earlier this month, show the local authority maintained its carbon footprint reduction from   to  , with a . per cent drop from , tCOeto , tCOe.Councillor Norman Hampshire, environment spokesperson, said: ldquoIn our Climate Change Strategy ndash, which was approved in January , the council set out its commitment to continue to reduce emissions towards reaching net zero and to continue to improve the integrity of our emissions data and reporting mechanisms.The report noted that the latest figures continue the trend for a ldquosignicant and steady overall reduction in the councilrsquos corporate emissions since a baseline measurement in  . This year, the council stated, further improvements were made to a system for recording the emissions from its vehicle fleet to further improve accuracy.Mr Hampshire added: ldquoEast Lothian is a rapidly growing area itrsquos extremely encouraging that we are continuing to make good progress in our total emissions reduction year on year in the context of signicant population growth.ldquoWe continue to focus on specic considerations around developments within the councilrsquos estate and aim to ensure appropriate energy efficient infrastructure and technology is utilised as appropriate.ldquoFollowing the enactment of the Climate Change Act  public bodies across the country are expected to lead by example in tackling climate change and contributing towards achieving the ambitious net zero emissions target.Mr Hampshire said: ldquoThe council is a provider of services, a major employer and a procurer of goods and services across the county and just last month saw the adoption of a new sustainable procurement policy.ldquoThe work of the council this year has been greatly impacted by Covid- but any longer term effects the pandemic has had on the councilrsquos energy use, fleet mileage and corporate emissions will not be detailed until next yearrsquos annual report, which will cover the financial year  .The full report, lsquoEast Lothian Councilrsquos Public Sector Climate Change Reporting  rsquo, can be viewed at eastlothian.gov.uk meetings meeting  members_library_service

title: grand-designs-experiment-north-berwick-high-street-refused
story: Architect Robin Sutherland came up with the Passivhaus build for his family after they bought property at  High Street, North Berwick.With the front of the property refurbished into a new shop front with offices for the architect upstairs , he turned his attention to designing a family home on the strip of land behind it, which measures . metres long and . metres wide.Plans showed the ground floor having a bathroom and study bedroom, with parking bays at the front and a courtyard garden at the rear a bedroom, kitchen diner and outside roof terrace on the first floor and, on the second floor, a living room and bedroom.However, despite his design being described by one councillor as ldquoextraordinary, his vision for his new home clashed with neighbours, the community council and ward councillors, who claimed it went against the arearsquos conservation status.And despite planning officers ruling that the proposed house met its policies, the planning committee refused planning permission by six votes to five.Mr Sutherlandrsquos proposed home would have had room widths of . metres.In his design statement to planners, he said: ldquoThe site is very narrow, with a width of approximately . metres however, an internal room width of .m is achievable, which is comfortably within the bounds of normally scaled domestic space.But Councillor Jane Henderson, ward member, told the committee that the width of the home would be ldquonot much wider than a shipping container, my goodness gracious.She said: ldquoI am not convinced this is the best place for a Grand Designs experiment, adding: ldquoJust because theoretically it can be done does not make it right.Grand Designs is a popular and long-running home improvements TV show where unique and daringly designed homes are built.Neighbours overlooking the proposed house had objections about the impact of the three-storey home on their privacy, in particular a proposed roof terrace. And they raised concerns about the use of zinccladding on the walls and roo.Mr Sutherland highlighted other properties in North Berwick which had zinc cladding Councillor Jim Goodfellow, ward member, described the proposed new house as a ldquozinc house.North Berwick Community Council also lodged objections, citing the impact of the zinc materials on the conservation area and on neighboursrsquo privacy and amenity.Councillor Norman Hampshire, planning convenor, backed the proposals, highlighting that planning officers had ruled the design met the councilrsquos relevant planning policies.He said the house was something which would, in time, be viewed as an ldquoattractive addition to the townrsquos conservation area.FAREWELL: Hotel owners check out after familys near  years in businessHowever, Councillor Willie Innes, council leader, pointed to the strength of concerns from the community and said that while he appreciated the ldquoextraordinary way the architect had created the design for the house, it was in the wrong location.He said: ldquoI accept what local members are saying. I think the overall impact would be too signicant.The committee voted by six members to five to refuse planning permission.Mr Sutherland declined to comment following the decision.

title: iain-gray-msp-independence-route-map-beggars-belief
story: However, the reality is very dferent, with work ongoing on numerous important pieces of legislation.One of these was the Protection of Workers Bill, which passed its final stage last week. It introduces a new statutory offence of assaulting, threatening or abusing a retail worker and provides further legal protections when the worker is carrying out their statutory duties, such as age restricted sales.Another Bill that passed its first stage last week, and which I was pleased to speak in support of, was the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child Bill. This legislation will directly incorporate the UNCRC into Scottish law and make it unlawful for public authorities to act incompatibly with the UNCRC requirements.There is a local link to this work, too, thanks to StreetsAhead Tranent.This project saw children from the Ross High School cluster visit Geneva to share their work directly with the UN Committee on the Rights of the Child, and other children and adults from around the world.On a less positive note, the Culpable Homicide Bill fell last week after SNP MSPs failed to support it.It sought to ensure suitable convictions would take place in the event of a workplace death, where recklessness or gross negligence of iniduals, companies or organisations could be proven. It is a missed opportunity to act and help save lives at work.One political development we could do without is the SNP governmentrsquos new -point route map to independence.It really does beggar belief that even in the middle of the pandemic they continue to make breaking up the UK their top priority.It seems clear that its focus must be on recovering from the pandemic and uniting the country.

title: dementia-friendly-east-lothian-organise-free-virtual-concert-scottish-singer
story: Bruce Davies, who has been a full-time professional entertainer since , will be undertaking the virtual performance, called lsquoCelebrating Scotlandrsquo, on Thursday .Dementia Friendly East Lothian has organised the event and it begins at .pm the group aims to make communities in East Lothian more welcoming and le better for those living with dementia.Brucersquos musical celebration is being held both on Facebook Live and on Zoom.For those wishing to watch via Zoom are asked to email Maya@dfel.org.uk for the link.Those at Dementia Friendly East Lothian say that while haggis is optional, singing and wearing tartan are encouraged.For more information visit Dementia Friendly East Lothianrsquos Facebook page or the event page.Bruce is currently the singing host in Edinburghrsquos lsquoSpirit of Scotland Showrsquo, he has also performed at the Edinburgh Fringe and Folk Festivals as well as ious parts of America. title: steeplejacks-tackle-maintenance-st-michaels-church
story: The specialist team completed an inspection of the lightning conductors and steeple, removed vegetation and also carried out work on an opening where coverings had fallen inwards.The project was undertaken by Northern Steeplejacks, which is based at Newtongrange in Midlothian.The cockerel weathervane was refurbished under a previous contract.There has been a church on the site since the th century.The present church was built in  to the design of Robert Nisbet and the steeple is recorded as being by the architect William Sibbald, following his earlier design for that at St Andrewrsquos, George Street, Edinburgh, in .This project was to a large extent the brainchild of the illustrious minister of St Michaelrsquos, Dr Alexander lsquoJupiterrsquo Carlyle.The kirk stands on the site of a Roman praetorium and replaces a medieval church. It has an Adam-style ceiling and stained glass.The building was substantially altered to accommodate the innovative new trend in worship ndash a pipe organ ndash in . This Lewis organ was quite radical in its design at that time.St Michaelrsquos boasts some notable ministers in its post-Reformation history, such as the second minister, The Rev Andrew Blackhall, who was an accomplished composer of music.The Rev Alexander Carlyle was a pioneer of the Sunday School movement and his autobiography shed light on a turbulent period in Scotlandrsquos history.The Rev John Beveridge was a campaigner for the renewal of worship and distinguished himself by his devotion to duty during a cholera outbreak.In , St Michaelrsquos celebrated the th anniversary of the present building, which is listed lsquoCategory Arsquo, meaning it is of special architectural or historical interest and is an outstanding example of a particular period, style or building type.

title: weekend-coronavirus-vaccine-clinic-set-riverside-medical-practice
story: They will be invited to attend on Saturday to receive their jabs from GP partner Dr Catherine Cameron, nurses Diane Fyffe, Delia Marriott, Sarah Falconer and Gillian Fulton, and general practice paramedic Tracy Henry.Almost  per cent of the first priority group have been vaccinated already and, while Riverside and other GP practices across the country are still constrained by vaccine supply, the third vaccine allocation sent to Riverside was large enough to warrant a weekend clinic.Staff will soon start to vaccinate people aged - and those in the shielding group who are defined on medical grounds as extremely vulnerable from Covid-.The practice, based at Musselburgh Primary Care Centre, is the largest in East Lothian and one of the biggest in Scotland, with about , patients.Dr Joanna Stenke, GP partner, said: ldquoOur dedicated team are delighted to be coming into the practice at the weekend to get as many of the first priority group vaccinated as possible.ldquoGPs across Scotland were asked by the Scottish Government to vaccinate registered patients aged  and over who can attend the clinic in person and wersquore pleased to have been able to vaccinate  of this group already at Riverside. Most people have been delighted when wersquove phoned to offer an appointment, and we really enjoy making the call.She added: ldquoThis weekend clinic will see the majority of our remaining patients aged  and over vaccinated, with the remaining few to be vaccinated when we receive our next vaccine allocation.ldquoWersquoll then begin to offer vaccine appointments to registered patients aged - who can attend the clinic in person along with shielders of all ages. Shielders are defined as those who have already received a shielders letter from the government or their GP.Eligible patients will be contacted by phone by the team at Riverside. Patients should wait to be contacted to help the team get the vaccines out to patients as soon as possible.The next priority group, those aged - years, will also start to be vaccinated shortly - but this is currently planned to take place in mass vaccination venues and health board clinics rather than in GP surgeries.Queen Margaret University has been named as a mass vaccination venue.Local health board teams will vaccinate housebound registered patients and these patients should wait to be contacted by them direct.For more information about the vaccination programme at Riverside, including which vaccine is being used and a weekly update on numbers vaccinated, visit www.theriversidepractice covid--vaccination-underway-at-riversidePatients are being advised to continue to follow local and national restrictions after receiving the vaccine.A spokesperson for the East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnership said: ldquoI can say that the vaccination programme in East Lothian is progressing well, in line with the planned national roll-out.But East Lothian MSP Iain Gray has described the speed of the Covid- vaccine rollout in East Lothian as a whole as ldquounacceptable.: Speed of Covid vaccine rollout labelled lsquounacceptablersquoThe latest figures show that , people had been vaccinated across the county up to Sunday, January  ndash . per cent of the countyrsquos population. This placed East Lothian as the third slowest council area in Scotland for vaccines being administered.John Swinney MSP, Deputy First Minister, insisted this week that the national vaccination programme was on track.He said: ldquoGood progress has been made on the delivery of the vaccine for over-s. We have got to  per cent of care home residents, who are most at risk of morbidity from Covid.ldquoWe are in a majority now in over-s and that task will be completed by the end of the first week in February.

title: stuart-rollo-wins-porsche-macan-gts-70-000-botb-competition

title: bogus-john-knoxs-house-haddington
story: According to a paper by the local historian J.H. Jamieson, in the third volume of the East Lothian Antiquarian and Field Naturalistsrsquo Society, the house on the eastern side of the Gfordgate pointed out as Knoxrsquos birthplace was demolished prior to .In , none less than celebrated essayist and historian Thomas Carlyle made sure that an oak was planted and a memorial stone erected on the site this oak still remains today and is quite a majestic tree.It is a mysterious matter that there was a lsquoJohn Knoxrsquos Housersquo in Haddington in Edwardian times, the subject of several picture postcards, including one by the notable North Berwick artist Reginald Phillimore.The truth appears to be, according to the Jamieson article, that another house, situated on the western side of the Gfordgate, was pointed out to the tourists as the birthplace of John Knox, although it only dated back to the th century.The mischievous locals received generous tips from the gullible tourists, who had come from Edinburgh and beyond to see the great Reformerrsquos birthplace.A rustic-looking building, this bogus lsquoKnoxrsquos Housersquo, was still standing as recently as the s, but it does not remain today.It is curious that Knoxrsquos birthplace is not definitely known, with some historians advocating the villages of Gford or Morham the house in Edinburgh pointed out as lsquoJohn Knoxrsquos Housersquo was never inhabited by the Reformer, but was named from an obscure popular tradition arising in the early th century nor is the exact site of Knoxrsquos grave known, although a plaque is said to mark it in what is today the car park in Parliament Square.

title: gardening-column-succulents-cacti
story: In this column wersquore looking at succulents and cacti ndash a group of indoor plants that are so easy that theyrsquoreimpossible to get wrong.Succulents and cacti tend to be grouped together because they can store water in their tissues that enables them to survive hot, dry conditions. This adaptation means that they are ideally suited to being houseplants, particularly in homes where the owners are forgetful waterers!Succulent is a general description for plants that have tissues adapted to store water but doesnrsquot refer to a specic plant. On the other hand, cactus is a botanical name for plants belonging to the plant family Cactaceae and, for specic physiological reasons, may not always be regarded as succulents.Succulent suggestionsAmongst the toughest, most robust indoor succulents is the sanseveria, a wide range of plants whose common names include mother-in-lawrsquos tongue , snake plantand birds nest plant .With bold, thick, simple leaves, theyrsquore almost sculptural in appearance, tolerant of low light levels and, because they require minimal attention, theyrsquore an obvious choice for those with little or no experience of houseplants.Sanseveria are particularly good at improving the indoor air quality theyrsquore known to remove air pollutants including formaldehyde, xylene and toluene and, because they convert carbon dioxide to oxygen at night, theyrsquore popular bedroom plants.Another group of plants that are particularly easy to care for are the aloes, which the ancient Egyptians called lsquoimmortality plantsrsquo because they are almost indestructible.The natural healing benefits of aloe vera has made it popular for centuries and is iously credited with the ability to soothe irritated or burned skin, improve skin, hair, oral hygiene and digestion and to treat acne and arthritis.Like sanseveria, aloe requires very little care, tolerates low light levels and infrequent watering, removes air-borne pollutants and oxygenates the air at night, which aids sleep.One of our favourite succulents is the echiveria, which grows in compact rosettes of succulent, sometimes coloured leaves from which flowering stalks may grow.These plants like a reasonable amount of light, some dilute feed when actively growing and prefer under-watering to over-watering. A happy echiveria will produce little plantlets which can be removed and grown into new plants.Carefree cactusIt would be impossible to talk about easy-to-care for plants without mentioning cacti, which have well-developed survival adaptations.Most cacti have developed spines which in fact are highly modied leaves. Not only do these spines help prevent the plant being grazed, but they also reduce the airflow around the plant, which helps it conserve water.Photosynthesis takes place on the stemand its shallow, far-reaching root system enables the cactus to react quickly and absorb any water reaching the ground.Whilst the enormous tree-like cacti of the American desert may be the first cactus that springs to mind, wersquove highlighted some interesting houseplant types below that are incredibly easy to look after and certainly wonrsquot take over your home!There are many dferent shapes of cacti, including round, flat, columnar, smooth, bumpy, ribbed and fluted, and itrsquos important to note that some of these actually change shape depending on how much water is stored in the stem at the time!Not all cacti have fully developed spines. For example, the popular schlumbergera, of which the best-known culti is the Christmas-flowering cactus, has less modied leaves which look like lsquoteethrsquo along the edge of their stems. Their stems grow in lsquosegmentsrsquo and resemble flattened pads, with their flowers being produced at the end of the segments.Although the Christmas-flowering culti is most popular in the UK, there are dferent cultis which flower at dferent times of the year.In their natural habitat, schlumbergera grow on trees or in rocks and generally enjoy shady habitats with high humidity, making them an ideal choice for bathrooms.If yoursquore looking for an unusual and interesting but easy-to-care-for indoor hanging plant, you might consider the aporocactus ndash a group of tree-growing cactus that grow well in a hanging pot.For a cactus with impact, the gymnocalycium mihanovichii is a sure winner. The top part of the stem on this cactus lacks green pigmentand can be bright red, yellow or other amazing colours.So,yoursquore looking for a plant that thrives on neglect, hopefully wersquove given you some ideas!Just remember that the golden rule for cacti and succulents is to under-water rather than over-water ndash too much moisture will cause disease and rot.For more information, take a look on our website at www.merryhatton

title: mary-contini-column-food-thought-covid
story: To be able to buy vegetables from the likes of Crunchy Carrot in Dunbar or Phantassie in East Linton is my foodie heaven !It is probably more expensive to shop locally and, as you need to drive to dferent outlets, it does take longer.For hard-pressed working families, this is not always an option. A big supermarket shop, with selections of everything we need, is a necessary part of most householdsrsquo routine.This year, however, this never-ending choice and supply has clearly been disrupted. The perfect storm of pandemic, Brexit and bad weather has resulted in frequently empty shelves. Some products are unavailable.Prices are increasing. Recent reports of supermarkets recalling food ranges such as pre-prepared seafoods and cheese spreads because of risk of contamination indicate trouble in the system.The food journey to supermarket shelf is long. Ingredients are pulled together from multiple counties, even countries.The brilliant exercise in sourcing, logistics, and extending the le of ingredients has successfully given us the lsquowhat you want when you fancy itrsquo way of le we have become used to.But, having been forced to stop and reassess how we shop, eat and live, I suspect many families are keen to step back from this corporate sales pitch and rediscover the local delights on our doorstep.Steady queues at the doors of local food shops, increased numbers of local food delivery services and fish vans bringing an ever-increasing selection of fish from the pier to our kitchen sink is, to my mind, a positive outcome of a dreadful situation.Milk daily on the doorstep. title: tranent-shopkeepers-licence-sell-alcohol-held-six-months
story: Manish Kumar, who runs the Day-Today store, Tranent, appeared before East Lothian Licensing Board todayto ask for a personal licence to sell alcohol in the shop.Mr Kumar, who was described as the tenant of the shop, was asked to bring his application to the board after a previous hearing heard he had lodged it with Edinburghs Licensing Board as he lived in the city.But at a virtual meeting, the board ruled against granting the licence - instead ordering a six-month continuation of his application.The board heard that there was a possible pending court appearance involving Mr Kumar in relation to the alleged sale of alcohol to an underage male last October.Members of the board were told that no date for any court appearance had yet been scheduled and it was unclear whether a case would be going ahead.Board members took a -minute recess to discuss Mr Kumars application privately before ruling against issuing a licence.Councillor Fiona Dugdale, board convenor, said: "We are not happy to granttoday and would like to continue this for six months."

title: east-lothian-coastal-car-park-charging-sites-proposed
story: There are also proposals to extendparking charges to include two currently exempt car parks - at Back Sands and Levenhall Links, Musselburgh - and introduce overflow car parks at popular sites.East Lothian Council has launched a Land Management Review after a year in which record numbers of tourists descended on beauty spots.Among proposals being put forward are the creation of a new park exclusively for motorhomes at Barns Ness, near Dunbar, and a complete ban on overnight stays at coastal car parks.The consultation alsosuggests a clampdown on campers by insisting only wild camping is allowed in coastal areas and defines wild campers as those who camp as part of a pedestrian or cycled journey, with equipment they can carry on them and in groups of four or less.The proposals come after an unprecedented number of visitors were seen in East Lothian during the pandemic last year with numbers estimated at million -  per cent more than in a normal year.A report lodged in the councils members library service describes a "motorhome invasion" in the summer with parking bays taken up.And it said July  was the busiest day in  years, according to East Lothians countryside rangers service.Coastal car parks overflowed with people parking illegally on access roads and wild camping incidents regularly saw groups of  tents gathered at any given site.The report said it was only face to face engagement with visitors by countryside rangers which helped the county avoid many of the dirty camping issues other Scottish beauty spots experienced but there were still issues with indiscriminate toileting and litter as well as fires causing damage to woodlands.Between June and August, , tents and motorhomes were recorded in the coastal car parks.RECAP: Patrols carried out after human waste left by campersThe report said: "The number of tents at both Yellowcraig and Tyninghame was particularly high and the most affected compared to other coastal sites, with one weekend recording tents at Tyninghame and  tents at Yellowcraig."Associated issues were fire damage to the SSSI grassland and dune habitats, irresponsible toileting, tree damage bythose scavenging for wood and generally camping out with the guidance with the Scottish Outdoor Access Code, to the inconvenience of other users or detriment of their experience with coastal sites."New camping information signage was installed although high levels of camping and fire sites persisted."The proposed changes to car parking rules would mean motorhomes would be unable to use any coastal car parks overnight and would be directed to the new park.The report revealed: "The council is in talks with Tarmac for Barns Ness to be a potential site specically designated for motorhomes." In relation to existing coastal car park provision, it is proposed to ban overnight parking, and control through a twilight parking enforcement service in the evenings and overnight."In this way, motorhome and campers can be directed to purpose-built accommodation. This will ensure that the coastal car parks which have been established as a resource will enable locals and visitors to enjoy the coast as opposed to being motorhome sites."A ban of overnight parking will effectively close the car parks for vehicle use and prohibit any vehicle from staying overnight "The proposed changes would also see an increased stretch of coastal road where parking is banned.No waiting restrictions are proposed for the B between Dean Road and Seton Sands Caravan Park and on the south side from Dean Road to Lyars Road, Longniddry.The public consultation went online today ateastlothianconsultations policy-partnerships land-management-rules
